Award.AwardTitle: Computers & Scientific Discovery 7: Chemistry, Computer Science and Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Computers in Scientific Discovery 7 (CSD7) is an interdisciplinary workshop that will bring together researchers with expertise in chemistry, graph theory, combinatorics, the generation of combinatorial structures, and automated conjecture making in order to make computational and theoretical advances in chemistry. The workshop will be held at Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA from August 04, 2014 to August 08, 2014. CSD7 is the 7th in this series. The previous six CSD workshops took place in six different countries.

Chemistry is the study of matter and its transformations, and it is an experimental science, but chemical theory has an underlying mathematical structure. Carbon is the most versatile of chemical elements in combining with itself to form chains, rings, sheets, cages and periodic 3D structures. New forms of carbon, discovered in the past two decades, have potential applications in molecular electronics, chemistry and materials science. Exploitation of these opportunities will depend on collaborations of scientists from many disciplines. CSD7 provides the ideal venue for establishing these collaborations, allowing young researchers to meet and interact with senior experts in their fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computers in Scientific Discovery 7 (CSD7)}  was an  interdisciplinary workshop that brought together researchers with expertise in chemistry, graph theory, combinatorics, the generation of combinatorial structures, and automated conjecture making in order to make computational and theoretical advances in chemistry. It was the sequel to a series of six previous Computers in Scientific Discovery (CSD) workshops, that have taken place in six countries.  The workshop was held at Virginia Commonwealth University from July 19--23, 2015. There were 42 participants from 11 countries, including 10 undergraduate and graduate students;  there were 11 Keynote Addresses, 21 Contributed Talks, and ample time for discussion and interaction.

Chemistry is the study of matter and its transformations, and is an experimental science, but it has an underlying mathematical structure.  Carbon is the most versatile of chemical elements in combining with itself to form chains, rings, sheets, cages and periodic 3D structures. New forms of carbon, discovered in the past two decades, have potential applications in molecular electronics, chemistry and materials science. Exploitation of these
opportunities will depend on collaborations of scientists from many disciplines. CSD 7 provided an ideal venue for establishing these collaborations, and allowed young researchers to meet and interact with senior experts in their fields. 

The CSD7 program and slides for the talks may be found at: http://go.vcu.edu/csd7.

Intellectual Merit.  The scientific objective of this workshop was to combine the expertise of a group of researchers from graph theory, chemistry and computer science to make advances in chemistry, especially in carbon chemistry, the source of three recent Nobel prizes in chemistry, and especially connected to molecule and nano-circuit design. In this workshop, specialists from chemistry, mathematics and computer science, from research departments across the world, came together to work on ways of improving the predictive power of chemical theories. The main target was the prediction of structures and properties of carbon nanostructures.

Broader Impacts. This workshop promoted teaching, training, and learning, both through the lectures, interaction and collaboration of well-known international scientists, but also through the exposure of students and junior researchers to the latest research of these senior researchers, and in the connections they made that are essential to their future success.
